resource.chars:
Thirdly, if the extremity of the intestine 
either in <u>Rhynchonella <\u> or in <u>Waldheimia <\u> 
be cut off and transferred to a glass plate 
it may readily be examined <s>with a <\s>
microscopically with high powers &
it is then easily observable that its 
fibrous investment is a completely 
shut one - In <u>Rhynchonella <\u> 
the enlarged caecum is often full 
of Diatomaceous shells but it is impossible 
to force them out at its end - while 
if any aperture existed they would 
of course readily be so extruded 
<s>I trust then <\s> However anomalous 
physiologically then - this caecal 
termination of the intestine in a 
Molluscous genus may be - I see no 
way of escaping from the conclusion that 
in the <u>Terebratulidae <\u> (at any rate in 
these two species) it really obtains
